Author: Be-skeptical

Comment: Yup. But he has put Jerome Powell in an impossible situation. His tariffs will cause both inflation and a recession. To combat the recession, Powell needs to cut interest rates as Trump wants. To combat inflation, Powell needs to increase interest rates, which Trump doesn't want. Powell can only fix one of Trump's self-inflicted wounds by making the other one worse.   But since Paul Volcker, the accepted wisdom in the Federal Reserve is that inflation should be fixed first in order to avoid stagflation. And the whole reason that central banks, like the Federal Reserve, are fairly independent, is to avoid running monetary policy according to election cycles.   The Fed could indeed lower interest rates to make people in the USA feel a bit wealthier right now but this would pretty much guarantee stagflation similar (or worse) than that of the 1970s. And that level of stagflation would end up requiring much worse medicine later to fix. At most, Powell can hold rates somewhat steady and try to manage the crisis that Trump created without really solving either problem.

Comment: If there is one thing I've learned from people on reddit it's that the actual start of the downturn does not count. For them it only starts when it affects them or when the media out and out tells them it's already started.    There's still people that think Trump is a good idea and there's still people who haven't yet had their daily lives affected too much. Until then it's just someone else's problem or it's just locker room talk. They still don't understand how much damage Trump and Republicans did during the first 4 years or the daily Republican sabotage that has been going on for decades...   China made some, changes, recently.    China Just Turned Off U.S. Supplies Of Minerals Critical For Defense & Cleantech   https://cleantechnica.com/2025/04/05/china-just-turned-off-u-s-supplies-of-minerals-critical-for-defense-cleantech/   > What China did wasn’t a ban, at least not in name. They called it export licensing. Sounds like something a trade lawyer might actually be excited about. But make no mistake: this was a surgical strike. They didn’t need to say no. They just needed to say “maybe later” to the right set of paperwork. These licenses give Beijing control over not just where these materials go, but how fast they go, in what quantity, and to which politically convenient customers. >  > The U.S.? Let’s just say Washington should get comfortable waiting behind the rope line. The licenses have to be applied for and the end use including country of final destination must be clearly spelled out. Licenses for end uses in the U.S. are unlikely to be approved. What’s astonishing is how predictable this all was. China has spent decades building its dominance over these supply chains, while the U.S. was busy outsourcing, divesting, and cheerfully ignoring every report that said, “Hey, maybe 90% dependence on a single country we keep starting trade wars with and rattling sabers at is a bad idea.” >  > Try ramping up your semiconductor fab or solar plant when your indium source just dried up. It’s a fun exercise in learning which of your suppliers used to be dependent on Beijing but never mentioned it in the quarterly call. >  > The materials China just restricted aren’t random. They’re chosen with the precision of someone who’s read U.S. product spec sheets and defense procurement orders. Start with dysprosium. If your electric motor needs to function at high temperatures—and they all do—then mostly it is using neodymium magnets doped with dysprosium. No dysprosium, no thermal stability. No thermal stability, no functioning motor in your F-35 or your Mustang Mach-E. China controls essentially the entire supply of dysprosium, and no, there is no magical mine in Wyoming or Quebec waiting in the wings. If dysprosium doesn’t come out of China, it doesn’t come out at all. It’s the spinal cord of electrification, and right now China’s holding the vertebrae. >  > So here we are. China has responded to Trump’s tariffs by cutting off U.S. supply of some of the most essential ingredients of the modern world.
